newsitem.title: SPAIN: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.
newsitem.headline: Peseta debt/interbank market closing report.

text.p: Spanish government bonds were holding initial losses right before the close on Tuesday, as dealers said the market was imitating its sister German market with no fresh domestic incentives.
"After the Bank of Spain left its 5.25 percent key rate unchanged as expected, we remained trapped in a very tight trading range for the whole day," a dealer said.
Another added that losses were due to the fall in Bunds, with the 10-year spread versus the German bonds trading at around 64 basis points, little changed from yesterday's level.
Long-bond future spent the day between 117.11 and 117.50.
Technical analysts said that long bond future is likely to continue this uninspired trade on Wednesday, moving between support at 117.05/10 and resistance at 117.50/60.
Tomorrow, the Spanish Treasury is auctioning six-month bills, whose yields are expected to remain unchanged from 5.051 percent set two weeks ago.
"After the Bank of Spain decided to hold its rate, I would not expect any change at tomorrow's auction," a dealer in Madrid said.
